title: Ukiyo-e: Bird's Eye View of Edo
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Janice Katz

Janice Katz: So this a panoramic bird’s-eye view of the city of Edo, known today as Tokyo, and this
painting is from the early 19 th century. It was just recently, before this painting was done, that Edo
actually became the largest city in the world in terms of population, larger than Paris, larger than Rome,
larger than London. Ukiyo-e—pictures of the floating world—is imagery that sprang up from life in this
urban setting. From people interacting with one another and enjoying the pleasures of the kabuki theater,
seasonal entertainments, the pleasure quarters. And it’s important to under where the floating world was
centered, where they are in the urban landscape so that you can understand how people were moving
about the city, how they were interacting with one another, the size of the city at the time.

On the pair of folding screens, notice the small people going about their daily business, going to temples,
shrines, working in the fields, enjoying themselves with seasonal activities and festivals; and these small
figures were then focused on and writ large on the hanging scrolls you see throughout the rest of the
exhibition.
